name: Evidentiality, appearance, hearsay, certainty
description: How Japanese marks information source and confidence—from visual appearance to hearsay to strong conviction (N3–N1).

entries.example_en: It looks like it’s going to rain.

entries.meaning: I heard that / it is said that (reported information)
entries.example_jp: 明日は寒くなるそうです。
entries.example_en: I heard that it will be cold tomorrow.

entries.meaning: it seems that / it appears that (reasoned or indirect evidence)
seems like / looks like (casual, subjective impression)
entries.example_jp: あの人は先生みたいです。
entries.example_en: That person seems like a teacher.

entries.meaning: apparently / I heard that / typical of (based on info or reputation)
entries.example_jp: 彼は来ないらしいです。
あの態度は怒っているに違いない。
entries.example_en: With that attitude, they must be angry.

entries.meaning: should; expected to; it stands to reason
entries.example_jp: もうすぐ着くはずです。
明日は雪かもしれない。
これは名作に相違ない。
先生によると、試験は延期とのことです。
entries.example_en: According to the teacher, the exam has been postponed.

entries.example_jp: 『学び』という言葉が好きです。

entries.example_en: Mountains can be seen in the distance.

entries.meaning: feel like; have a sense that
entries.example_jp: 今日はうまくいく気がする。
entries.example_en: I have a feeling things will go well today.

entries.example_jp: 彼はもう知っているに違いない。
そんなの失敗に決まってる。
その判断は正しいに相違ない。
彼は彼らしいやり方で解決した。
entries.example_en: He solved it in a way that's typical of him.
What time was it tomorrow again?
